question: The external structure of the x-ray tube consists of three parts?
answer: Support structure, Protective Housing and the Glass or Metal Enclosure

question: The internal structures of the x-ray tube are?
Frequently used. It consists of two perpendicular sets of ceiling-mounted rails. This allows for both longitudinal and transverse travel of the x-ray tube.
It attaches the x-ray tube housing to the rails , allowing for variable source-to-image receptor distance (SID)

Some ceiling-supported x-ray tubes have a single control that removes all locks, allowing the tube to 'float'. This lock should be used only for minor adjustments and should not be used to move the tube farther than about how many maters?
Has a single column with rollers at each end , one attached to a ceiling-mounted rail and the other attached to a floor-mounted rail.
A variation of Floor-to-Ceiling Support sytsem has the column positioned on a single floor support system with how many floor-mounted rails?
answer: One or two floor mounted rails

question: Shaped like a 'C'

Ceiling mounted and provide for very flexible x-ray tube positioning. Image receptor is attatched to the other end of the C-arm from the x-ray tube. Variations called L-arm and U-arm support are also common.
Three methods of supporting an x-ray tube and these are?
answer: Ceiling Support , Floor Support , and C-arm Support

question: Guards against excessive radiation exposure and electric shock.

It provides mechanical support for the x-ray tube and protects the tube from damage caused by rough handling.
The ______ around some x-ray tubes contains oil that serves as both an insulator against electric shock and as a thermal cushion to dissipate heat.
Allows the oil to expand when heated. If the expansion is too great, a microswitch is activated , so the tube cannot be used until it cools.

Special type of vacuum tube.

question: Certain types of x-ray tubes called ______ ared designed to be turned on and off very rapidly.
Used in portable capacitor discharge imaging systems and in digital subtraction angiography, digital radiography , and cineradiography.
This term is borrowed from vaccum tube electronics and refers to an element in the tube that acts as the switch.
In a grid-controlled x-ray tube , the ____ is the grid and therefore the exposure switch.
Cloud of electrons

Thermionic emision at low kVp and high mA can be space charge limited.
Not reached at lower kVp because of space charge limitations.

Type of anode that used in dental x-ray imaging systems , some portable imaging systems and other special purpose units in which high tube current and power are not required.
General-purpose x-ray tubes use the this type of anode because they must be capable producing high intensity x-ray beams in a short time.
The anode is the positive side of the x-ray tube ; it conducts electricity and radiates heat and contains target.
The anode serves three functions in an x-ray tube.

Area of the anode struck by the electrons from the cathode.

Is the transfer of heat by the emission of infrared radiation.
Transfer of energy from one area of an object to another.
Transfer of heat by the movement of a heated substance from one place to another.

question: Of the three rating charts, this is the most important because it conveys which radiographic techniques are safe and which techniques are unsafe for x-ray tube operation.

Of the three rating charts, this has a limited capacity for storing heat. Although heat is dissipated to the oil bath and x-ray tube housing , it is possible through prolonged use or multiple exposures to exceed the heat storage capacity of the anode.

The housing chart for the housing of the x-ray tube has a shape similar to that of the anode cooling chart and is used in precisely the same way.

Were not vacuum tubes but rather contained controlled quantities of gas within the enclosure.
